消防車趕到時，房屋已是一片火海。

blocks.def: a powerful feeling
examples:
Flames of passion swept through both of them.
他們倆一時間激情澎湃。

blocks.def: an angry or offensive email
blocks.trans: 憤怒（或無禮）的電子郵件
examples:
flame wars
電子郵件辱罵大戰

blocks.def: to burn (more) brightly
examples:
The fire flamed cosily in the hearth.
壁爐裡的火暖烘烘地燃燒著。
 The fire suddenly flamed (up).
火突然燒起來了。

blocks.def: If an emotion flames, you feel it suddenly and strongly.
examples:
Seeing the damage made hatred flame within her.
看到損毀的情況，她心頭燃起了仇恨之火。

blocks.def: to suddenly become hot and red with emotion
examples:
His face flamed (red) with anger.
他氣得臉通紅。

blocks.def: to send an angry or insulting email
blocks.trans: 寄送憤怒（或無禮）的電子郵件
examples:
Please don't flame me if you disagree with this message.
如果您不同意此信息的內容，也請不要給我發送惡意回信。

blocks.def: very confident in behaviour, and liking to be noticed by other people, for example because of the way you dress, talk, etc.
examples:
a flamboyant gesture
炫耀的姿態
 The writer's flamboyant lifestyle was well known.
這位作家的生活方式是出了名的誇張造作。

blocks.def: brightly coloured and easily noticed
examples:
His clothes were rather flamboyant for such a serious occasion.
他的衣著在如此嚴肅的場合顯得太豔麗了。

blocks.def: intended or likely to cause anger or hate
examples:
The men were using inflammatory language/making inflammatory remarks about the other team's supporters.
這些人惡語攻擊另一支球隊的支持者。

blocks.def: causing or related to swelling and pain in the body
to make something increase in size by filling it with air
examples:
He inflated the balloons with helium.
他給氣球充了氦氣。
 We watch the hot-air balloon slowly inflate.
我們看著熱氣球慢慢脹大。

blocks.def: to make something larger or more important
examples:
They inflated their part in the rescue every time they told the story.
他們每次講這個故事時都要誇大自己在營救中的貢獻。

blocks.def: to combine two or more separate things, especially pieces of text, to form a whole
blocks.trans: 合併，結合，混合（尤指文本）
examples:
She conflated the three plays to produce a fresh new work.
她成功地將三個劇本合併在一起，編出了一部令人耳目一新的新作品。

blocks.def: feeling less confident and positive than before
examples:
Her criticism left me feeling a bit deflated.
她的批評使我感到有點洩氣。

blocks.def: able to change or be changed easily according to the situation
blocks.trans: 可變動的；靈活的；可變通的
examples:
My schedule is flexible - I could arrange to meet with you any day next week.
我的時間安排很靈活——下周任何一天我都可以安排與你見面。

blocks.def: able to bend or to be bent easily without breaking
blocks.trans: 可彎曲的；柔韌的；有彈性的
examples:
Rubber is a flexible substance.
橡膠是一種有彈性的物質。
 Dancers and gymnasts need to be very flexible (= able to bend their bodies easily).
舞蹈演員和體操運動員的身體必須非常柔韌。

blocks.def: to (cause to) change direction, or to prevent something from being directed at you
examples:
The ball deflected off my shoulder, straight into the goal.
球打在我的肩膀上反彈進了球門。
 The crowd cheered as the goalkeeper deflected the shot.
當守門員把球擋出去的時候人們歡呼了起來。
 He deflected the ball away from the goal.
他把球擋出了球門。
 The prime minister deflected mounting criticism today by announcing tax cuts.
今天首相宣佈減稅，從而平息了越來越多的批評聲音。

blocks.def: A reflective surface sends back most of the light that shines on it and can therefore be seen easily.
thinking carefully and quietly
examples:
After hearing the news they sat in a quiet, reflective silence.
聽到這個消息後，他們都一聲不吭地坐著，陷入了沈思。

blocks.def: an active disagreement between people with opposing opinions or principles
examples:
There was a lot of conflict between him and his father.
他和父親之間存在著許多分歧。
 It was an unpopular policy and caused a number of conflicts within the party.
這項政策不得人心，在黨內引起了很多分歧。
 His outspoken views would frequently bring him into conflict with the president.
他對自己的看法總是直言不諱，這常常使他和總統發生爭執。

blocks.def: fighting between two or more groups of people or countries
examples:
We wish to avoid conflict between our countries if at all possible.
我們希望我們兩國之間能盡一切可能避免戰爭。

blocks.def: If beliefs, needs, or facts, etc. conflict, they are very different and cannot easily exist together or both be true.
blocks.trans: 不一致；發生抵觸；相矛盾；衝突
examples:
The results of the new research would seem to conflict with existing theories.
新的研究結果似乎和已有的理論相抵觸。

blocks.def: to fight or disagree actively
examples:
If the two sides conflict with each other again, it will be disastrous for party unity.
如果雙方再互相爭鬥下去，對黨內團結將是一場災難。

blocks.def: If a problem or illness afflicts a person or thing, they suffer from it.
examples:
It is an illness that afflicts women more than men.
患這種疾病的女性多於男性。
 a country afflicted by civil war
飽受內戰蹂躪的國家

blocks.def: to force someone to experience something very unpleasant
examples:
These new bullets are capable of inflicting massive injuries.
這些新型子彈可以造成重創。
 The suffering inflicted on these children was unimaginable.
這些孩子遭受的痛苦無法想像。

blocks.def: spending money in a way that wastes it and is not wise
examples:
She is well-known for her profligate spending habits.
她因恣意揮霍錢財而出名。

blocks.def: to grow or develop successfully
blocks.trans: 茁壯成長；繁榮；蓬勃發展
examples:
My tomatoes are flourishing this summer - it must be the warm weather.
今年夏天我的番茄長勢很好——這一定是天氣暖和的原因。
 Watercolour painting began to flourish in Britain around 1750.
1750年左右，水彩畫開始在英國興盛起來。

blocks.def: to move something in your hand in order to make people look at it
examples:
She came in smiling, flourishing her exam results.
她微笑著走進來，手裡揮舞著她的考試成績單。

blocks.def: If you do something with a flourish, you do it with one big, noticeable movement.
examples:
The waiter handed me the menu with a flourish.
侍者做了個誇張動作遞給我菜單。
 He took off his hat with a flourish.
他動作誇張地摘掉帽子。

blocks.def: with too much decoration or detail
examples:
a florid architectural style
華麗的建築風格
 florid prose/rhetoric
詞藻華麗的散文／修辭

blocks.def: (of a person's face) too red, especially in a way that is unhealthy
examples:
a florid complexion
潮紅的臉色

blocks.def: a substance that flows and is not solid
examples:
If you have a fever you should drink plenty of fluids.
如果發燒，應多喝流質。
 power steering fluid
助力轉向液
 The virus is contracted through exchange of bodily fluids (= liquids, such as blood, that come from the human body).
這種病毒透過體液感染。

blocks.def: smooth and continuous
examples:
fluid movements
流暢的動作

blocks.def: If situations, ideas, or plans are fluid, they are not fixed and are likely to change, often repeatedly and unexpectedly.
blocks.trans: （情況、想法或計劃）不固定的，易變的
examples:
The military situation is still very fluid.
軍事局勢依然很不穩定。

blocks.def: having a lot of money or owning a lot of things
examples:
affluent nations/neighbourhoods
富有國家／富人區

blocks.def: more than is needed or wanted
examples:
The report was marred by a mass of superfluous detail.
這篇報告壞就壞在裡面細枝末節的東西太多。

blocks.def: public or official
examples:
formal procedures
正式的程式
 a formal announcement
正式聲明

blocks.def: in appearance or by name only
blocks.trans: 形式上的；表面上的；名義上的
examples:
I am the formal leader of the project but the everyday management is in the hands of my assistant.
我是這個專案計劃名義上的領導人，但日常管理都由我的助理負責。

blocks.def: Formal language, clothes, and behaviour are suitable for serious or official occasions.
blocks.trans: （語言、服裝和行為）莊重的，正規的，適合正式場合的
examples:
a formal dinner party
正式宴會

blocks.def: Formal education or training is received in a school or college.
examples:
Tom had little formal education.
湯姆沒怎麽受過正規教育。

blocks.def: A formal garden is carefully designed and kept according to a plan, and it is not allowed to grow naturally.
blocks.trans: 精心佈置的，佈置井然的

blocks.def: a dance at which women wear fashionable, expensive dresses and men wear tuxedos or similar clothes
blocks.trans: 一種女士身穿時髦昂貴服裝、男士身穿燕尾服或類似服裝起舞的舞蹈

blocks.def: behaviour that follows the usual standards that are expected by a group or society
blocks.trans: （對社會規則的）遵從，遵守；從眾
examples:
It's depressing how much conformity there is in such young children.
這麽小的孩子就唯唯諾諾，真是令人沮喪。

blocks.def: the process of a product being made as it was designed, without mistakes or faults
examples:
Our goal is to improve conformity with customer requirements.
我們的目標是讓產品更加符合顧客的需要。
 conformity to specification
符合規格

blocks.def: relating to the time when someone or something is starting to develop in character
blocks.trans: 形成的；發展的；性格形成時期的
examples:
She spent her formative years in Africa.
她在非洲度過了性格形成時期。
 a formative experience
性格形成時期的一段經歷
 a formative period
性格形成時期

blocks.def: A formative assessment happens while a student is being taught about a subject, rather than at the end of a year or unit of work, in order to check their progress.
blocks.trans: （在學習某科目過程中，為檢查學習成果而進行的評量）形成性的
examples:
Continual formative assessment of student understanding through observation, student questioning, and written assignments helps teachers decide how well students are doing.
通過觀察、學生提問和書面作業對學生的理解進行持續的形成性評量，幫助教師掌握學生的學習情況。

blocks.def: containing or consisting of fixed and repeated groups of words or ideas
blocks.trans: 由套話堆砌的；公式化的
examples:
The text was dull and formulaic.
那篇文章乏味且套話連篇。

blocks.def: a military building designed to be defended from attack, consisting of an area surrounded by a strong wall, in which soldiers are based
examples:
The remains of the Roman fort are well preserved.
這個羅馬要塞的遺址保存完好。

blocks.def: to make someone feel uncomfortable, especially mentally
blocks.trans: （尤指在精神上）使感到不舒服，使不安

blocks.def: to make something stronger, especially in order to protect it
examples:
a fortified town
設防的城鎮
 They hurriedly fortified the village with barricades of carts.
他們匆忙用馬車搭起路障，加強村子的防禦。
 The argument had fortified her resolve to prove she was right.
這番爭論增強了她證明自己正確的決心。
 He fortified himself with a drink and a sandwich before driving on.
繼續開車之前，他喝了杯飲品吃了件三明治來增強體力。
 a fruit drink fortified with vitamin C (= with vitamin C added)
添加了維他命C的果汁飲品

blocks.def: a small piece or a part, especially when broken from something whole
blocks.trans: 小片，小塊；（尤指）碎片，碎塊
examples:
The road was covered with fragments of glass from the shattered window.
馬路上到處是車窗的碎玻璃片。
 Literary scholars are piecing together her last unpublished novel from fragments of a recently discovered manuscript.
文學研究者們正在把最近發現的她最後一部未發表小說的手稿殘片一點點拼湊起來。

blocks.def: to break something into small parts or to be broken up in this way
examples:
The satellite will fragment and burn up as it falls through the earth's atmosphere.
衛星墜經地球大氣層時會碎裂起火，化為灰燼。
 His day was fragmented by meetings and phone calls.
他一天的時間因為各種會議和電話而變得支離破碎。

blocks.def: easily upset or annoyed, and often complaining
examples:
a fractious child
暴躁的孩子

blocks.def: existing only in small parts and not complete
blocks.trans: 片斷的；零星的；不完整的
examples:
Reports are still fragmentary but it is already clear that the explosion has left many dead and injured.
雖然報道仍然是隻言片語，但已經很清楚爆炸造成了大量傷亡。

blocks.def: behaving in a silly way and not taking anything seriously
examples:
I think he sees her as a frivolous young woman.
我想他把她看成了輕浮的姑娘。

blocks.def: A frivolous activity or object is silly or not important rather than useful or serious.
examples:
I feel like doing something completely frivolous today.
今天我只想做點兒瑣事。

blocks.def: When water or glass, etc. refracts light or sound, etc., it causes it to change direction or to separate when it travels through it.
examples:
The glass prism refracted the white light into the colours of the rainbow.
玻璃棱鏡將白色光折射成彩虹的七色光。

blocks.def: not affected by a treatment, change, or process
examples:
This is a chronic and disabling condition that is refractory to treatment.
這是一種慢性致殘的症狀，對治療的反應不佳。

blocks.def: difficult to control; unwilling to obey
examples:
a refractory child
不聽話的孩子

blocks.def: the right to vote in an election, especially to vote for representatives in a government
blocks.trans: （尤指選舉議會等機構代表的）選舉權，投票權
examples:
universal suffrage (= the right of all adults to vote)
普選權

blocks.def: the crime of getting money by deceiving people
examples:
credit card fraud
信用卡詐騙
 He is fighting extradition to Hong Kong to face trial on fraud charges.
他正在力爭免於被引渡到香港就詐騙指控接受審判。

blocks.def: someone who deceives people by saying that they are someone or something that they are not
examples:
She was a psychic who was later revealed to be a fraud.
她是一個通靈巫師，後來被發現是個騙子。

blocks.def: dishonest and illegal
examples:
A worrying trend for insurers has been a rise in fraudulent claims.
令保險公司不安的是，詐騙性的索賠呈上升趨勢。

blocks.def: intended to deceive
examples:
They claim that the fall in unemployment is based on a fraudulent manipulation of statistics.
他們聲稱失業率下降是對統計資料進行欺騙性操縱的結果。

blocks.def: to face, meet, or deal with a difficult situation or person
blocks.trans: 面對，面臨；遭遇；直面，正視
examples:
As she left the court, she was confronted by angry crowds who tried to block her way.
她離開法庭時，憤怒的人群試圖攔住她的去路。
 It's an issue we'll have to confront at some point, no matter how unpleasant it is.
不管它有多討厭，我們終究要面對這個問題。
 I thought I would stay calm, but when I was confronted with/by the TV camera, I got very nervous.
我以爲我會保持鎮靜，可是面對電視鏡頭，我卻變得緊張萬分。

blocks.def: extreme rudeness without any ability to understand that your behaviour is not acceptable to other people
examples:
He was silent all through the meal and then had the effrontery to complain that I looked bored!
在飯桌上他自始至終一言不發，到頭來卻有臉抱怨我一副百無聊賴的樣子。

blocks.def: a person who has escaped from their own country for political, religious, or economic reasons or because of a war
examples:
Thousands of refugees fled across the border.
數以千計的難民越過邊境逃入鄰國。

blocks.def: a person who is running away or hiding from the police or a dangerous situation
examples:
Thousands of fugitives are fleeing from the war-torn area.
數以千計的難民逃離被戰爭蹂躪的地方。
 Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid were fugitives from justice (= they ran away to avoid being tried in court).
布奇‧凱西迪和日舞小子都是逃犯。

blocks.def: (especially of thoughts or feelings) lasting for only a short time
blocks.trans: （尤指想法或感覺）短暫的，暫時的
examples:
a fugitive impression
短暫的印象

blocks.def: relating to a fugitive
examples:
Fugitive families who have fled the fighting in the cities are now trying to survive in the mountains.
那些逃離城市戰火的家庭正設法在山區生存下來。

blocks.def: shining with a bright light
examples:
the beauty of her refulgent face
她熠熠生輝的面龐所表現出的美麗

blocks.def: to criticize strongly
examples:
I had to listen to Michael fulminating against the government.
我不得不聽著麥克譴責政府。

blocks.def: an occasion when an organization, state, etc. is established
examples:
the foundation of a new state
新州的建立

blocks.def: an organization that has been created in order to provide money for a particular group of people in need of help or for a particular type of study
examples:
the British Heart Foundation
英國心臟健康基金會
 the Environmental Research Foundation
環境研究基金會

blocks.def: the first year of infant school, previously known as reception
examples:
a foundation class/teacher
幼兒學校基礎班課堂／教師
 Her youngest child starts (in) foundation in September.
她最小的孩子九月份上幼兒學校基礎班。

blocks.def: the structures below the surface of the ground that support a building
examples:
The foundations will have to be reinforced to prevent the house from sinking further into the ground.
地基必須進行加固以防房屋繼續下陷。

blocks.def: to be untrue
examples:
These allegations are completely without foundation.
這些指控完全沒有根據。

blocks.def: a type of make-up that is spread over the skin of the face, usually before other make-up is put on, giving it a better and more even colour and hiding unwanted marks
to confuse and very much surprise someone, so that they are unable to explain or deal with a situation
examples:
An elderly man from Hull has confounded doctors by recovering after he was officially declared dead.
赫爾市的一位老人在被正式宣佈死亡後居然活了過來，令醫生們大惑不解。
 The singer confounded her critics with a remarkable follow-up album.
這位歌手隨後又推出了一張不同凡響的專輯，令評論家們大感意外。

blocks.def: someone who establishes an organization
examples:
She is the founder and managing director of the company.
她是公司的創辦者兼總經理。

blocks.def: (especially of a boat) to fill with water and sink
examples:
The ferry foundered in a heavy storm, taking many of the passengers and crew with it.
這艘渡船在一次強風暴中沉沒，很多乘客和船員遇難。

blocks.def: to be unsuccessful
examples:
Teaching computers to read and write has always foundered on the unpredictable human element in language.
教電腦讀寫的嘗試總是因為語言中不可預測的人為因素而宣告失敗。

blocks.def: felt or experienced very strongly or in an extreme way
examples:
His mother's death when he was aged six had a very profound effect on him.
他六歲時母親的過世對他的影響很大。
 The invention of the contraceptive pill brought about profound changes in the lives of women.
避孕藥的發明為女性的生活帶來了重大變化。
 Those two lines of poetry express perfectly the profound sadness of loss.
那兩行詩貼切表達了失去親人的深切悲痛。
 My grandfather has a profound mistrust of anything new or foreign.
我祖父對任何新生或外來事物有一種根深柢固的不信任。
 There was a note of profound irritation in his voice.
他的語氣中帶有強烈惱怒。

blocks.def: showing a clear and deep understanding of serious matters
examples:
profound truths/wisdom
深奧的真理／博大的智慧
 The review that I read said that it was "a thoughtful and profound film".
我看過的評論說它是一部「有創意、有深度的電影」。
 "Dying is easy - it's living that's the problem." "That was very profound of you, Steven."
「死很容易——活下去才是難題。」「史蒂文，你的話真深奧！」

blocks.def: the natural purpose (of something) or the duty (of a person)
examples:
The function of the veins is to carry blood to the heart.
靜脈的功能是將血液輸送回心臟。
 I'm not quite sure what my function is within the company.
我拿不太準自己在公司裡有甚麽職責。
 A thermostat performs the function of controlling temperature.
自動調溫器的功用是控制溫度。

blocks.def: an official ceremony or a formal social event, such as a party or a special meal, at which a lot of people are usually present
examples:
As a mayor, he has a lot of official functions to attend.
作爲市長，他要參加很多官方活動。
 I see her two or three times a year, usually at social functions.
我一年能見她兩三次，通常都是在社交聚會上。

blocks.def: the way in which something works or operates
examples:
It's a disease that affects the function of the nervous system.
這是一種影響神經系統功能的疾病。
 Studies suggest that regular intake of the vitamin significantly improves brain function.
研究顯示定期服用維生素會顯著增強大腦功能。

blocks.def: a process that a computer or a computer program uses to complete a task
examples:
a search/save/sort function
搜索／保存／排序功能

blocks.def: something that results from something else, or is the way it is because of something else
examples:
His success is a function of his having worked so hard.
他的成功是辛勤工作的結果。
 The low temperatures here are a function of the terrain as much as of the climate.
這裡的低溫是地形與氣候同時作用的結果。

blocks.def: (in mathematics) a quantity whose value depends on another value and changes with that value
examples:
x is a function of y.
x是y的函數。

blocks.def: to work or operate
examples:
You'll soon learn how the office functions.
你很快就會暸解辦事處的運作了。
 The television was functioning normally until yesterday.
一直到昨天電視機還一切正常。
 I'm so tired today, I can barely function.
我今天太累了，簡直動不了了。

blocks.def: done quickly, without taking care or interest
examples:
His smile was perfunctory.
他的笑容很敷衍。

blocks.def: to mix up someone's mind or ideas, or to make something difficult to understand
examples:
You're confusing him! Tell him slowly and one thing at a time.
你把他搞糊塗了！慢慢跟他講，一次說一件事。
 Stop confusing the issue (= making the problem unnecessarily difficult)!
別再把事情越搞越亂！

blocks.def: to mix up two separate things or people in your mind, imagining that they are one
examples:
You're confusing me with my sister - she's the singer.
你把我當成我姐姐了——她才是歌手。
 It's easy to confuse his films, because he tends to use the same actors.
他的影片很容易混淆，因爲他老是用相同的演員。

blocks.def: to prevent a bomb from exploding
examples:
Bomb disposal experts have defused a 110-pound bomb at a subway station this afternoon.
今天下午，排彈專家在一個地下鐵車站拆除了一枚110磅的炸彈。

blocks.def: to make a difficult or dangerous situation calmer by reducing or removing its cause
examples:
The two groups will meet next week to try to defuse the crisis/situation/tension.
雙方將於下週會面以求緩和危機／局面／緊張局勢。

blocks.def: to (cause something to) spread in many directions
examples:
Television is a powerful means of diffusing knowledge.
電視是傳播知識的有力工具。

blocks.def: to (cause a gas or liquid to) spread through or into a surrounding substance by mixing with it
blocks.trans: （使氣體或液體）彌漫，擴散，滲透
examples:
Oxygen diffuses from the lungs into the bloodstream.
氧氣從肺部滲透到血液之中。
 The drop of red dye diffused slowly in the water.
那滴紅色染料在水中慢慢擴散開來。

blocks.def: spread out and not directed in one place
examples:
a diffuse light
漫射光
 The company has become large and diffuse.
公司規模大了，業務範圍也更廣了。

blocks.def: not clear or easy to understand
examples:
a diffuse literary style
晦澀的文風

blocks.def: expressing welcome, approval, or pleasure in a way that shows very strong feeling
blocks.trans: 熱情的，熱情洋溢的；奔放的
examples:
They gave us such an effusive welcome it was quite embarrassing.
他們的歡迎儀式搞得如此熱烈，倒讓我們頗有些不好意思。

blocks.def: to fill someone or something with an emotion or quality
blocks.trans: 使（某人）充滿（某種感情）；將（某特性）注入（某物）
examples:
The pulling down of the Berlin Wall infused the world with optimism.
柏林圍牆的倒塌使全世界歡欣鼓舞。
 The arrival of a group of friends on Saturday infused new life into the weekend.
星期六一群朋友的到來給週末生活注入了新的活力。

blocks.def: If you infuse a drink or it infuses, you leave substances such as tea leaves or herbs in hot water so that their flavour goes into the liquid.
examples:
Allow the tea to infuse for five minutes.
讓茶泡五分鐘。

blocks.def: produced or given in large amounts
examples:
She was admitted to St Mary's Hospital with profuse bleeding.
她因大量出血被送入聖瑪麗醫院。
 The company accepted blame and sent us profuse apologies.
這家公司擔下了責任，一再向我們道歉。

blocks.def: to make something less clear and harder to understand, especially intentionally
blocks.trans: （尤指故意）使模糊，使糊塗，使困惑
examples:
She was criticized for using arguments that obfuscated the main issue.
她被批評故意使用混淆主要問題的論點。

blocks.def: to say or prove that a person, statement, opinion, etc. is wrong or false
blocks.trans: 駁斥；反駁；否認…的正確性（或真實性）
examples:
to refute a person/theory/argument/claim
駁斥一個人／理論／論點／說法

blocks.def: belonging or relating to genes (= parts of the DNA in cells) received by each animal or plant from its parents
examples:
a genetic defect/disease
基因缺陷／遺傳疾病

blocks.def: (the study of) the history of the past and present members of a family or families
blocks.trans: 家譜（學），宗譜（學）；家系，世系
examples:
I became interested in the genealogy of my family.
我對我家的家史産生了興趣。

blocks.def: a drawing showing the history of a family with all past and present members joined together by lines
the origin of something, when it is begun or starts to exist
examples:
The story had its genesis in a conversation the author had with his mother.
故事以作者與母親的一段對話開始。
 research into the genesis of cancer
對癌症病因的研究

blocks.def: the first book of the Bible, which describes how God made the world
blocks.trans: 《創世記》（《聖經》首卷，描述上帝創造世界）

blocks.def: the complete set of genetic material of a human, animal, plant, or other living thing
shared by, typical of, or relating to a whole group of similar things, rather than to any particular thing
examples:
The new range of engines all had a generic problem with their fan blades.
這一新系列的引擎有一個通病，就是風機葉片有問題。

blocks.def: generic drugs or other products do not have a trademark and are sold without the name of the company that produced them
blocks.trans: （藥物或商品）無專利的，未註冊的

blocks.def: a product, especially a drug, that is no longer owned or legally controlled by a particular company
blocks.trans: （尤指藥品）無專利的，不受某一廠商控制的
examples:
The biggest difference between the brand-name drugs and the generics is price.
品牌藥品和仿製藥品之間的最大差別是價格。

blocks.def: a style, especially in the arts, that involves a particular set of characteristics
examples:
What genre does the book fall into - comedy or tragedy?
這本書屬於甚麽體裁——喜劇還是悲劇？
 a literary/musical/film genre
文學體裁／音樂風格／電影類型

blocks.def: produced according to a particular model or style
blocks.trans: 屬於某類型的；按某種風格創作的
examples:
a genre movie
類型電影
 genre fiction
類型小説

blocks.def: a machine that produces electrical power
examples: The hospital's emergency generators are designed to cope with power cuts.

blocks.def: a machine or device that produces something
examples: a random number generator

blocks.def: a company or organization that produces something
examples: The two major electricity generators declined to comment.
Within the United States, the military is the largest generator of hazardous waste.
Tourism is Australia's greatest generator of employment.

blocks.def: friendly and pleasant
blocks.trans: 友善的；令人愉快的；怡人的
examples:
congenial company/surroundings
友善的夥伴／令人愉快的環境

blocks.def: to become worse in quality
examples:
Educational standards are degenerating year by year because of a lack of funds.
由於缺乏資金，教育水準連年下降。
 What was intended as a peaceful demonstration rapidly degenerated into violence.
一場原本和平的示威迅速演變成了暴力事件。

blocks.def: having low standards of behaviour
examples:
a degenerate young man
墮落的年輕人

blocks.def: someone with low standards of behaviour
examples:
They're just moral degenerates with no sense of decency.
他們這些人道德敗壞，毫無廉恥之心。

blocks.def: to make people have a particular feeling or make a situation start to exist
blocks.trans: 引起（某種感覺）；導致；産生
examples:
Her latest book has engendered a lot of controversy.
她的新作引起了很大爭議。
 The vice-president's speech did not engender confidence in his judgment.
部長的演講並未使人們對他的判斷産生信心。

blocks.def: friendly and pleasant
examples:
The teacher is very genial/has a genial manner.
這位老師非常友好／態度和藹。

blocks.def: consisting of parts or things that are very different from each other
examples:
Switzerland is a heterogeneous confederation of 26 self-governing cantons.
瑞士是一個由26個不同的自治州組成的聯邦。

blocks.def: consisting of parts or people that are similar to each other or are of the same type
blocks.trans: 由同類事物（或人）組成的；同類的；相似的
examples:
a homogeneous group/society
由同種族人組成的群體／社會
 The population of the village has remained remarkably homogeneous.
這個村莊的人口保持著顯著的同族特徵。

blocks.def: naturally existing in a place or country rather than arriving from another place
blocks.trans: 當地的；本土的，土生土長的
examples:
Are there any species of frog indigenous to the area?
這個地區是否有本地品種的青蛙？
 So who are the indigenous people of this land?
那麼誰是這塊土地的原住民？

blocks.def: (of a person) very intelligent and skilful, or (of a thing) skilfully made or planned and involving new ideas and methods
blocks.trans: （人）靈巧的；（物品等）製作精巧的；（方法等）巧妙的
examples:
an ingenious idea/method/solution
巧妙的主意／方法／解決辦法
 Johnny is so ingenious - he can make the most remarkable sculptures from the most ordinary materials.
強尼真是手巧——他可以用最普通的材料製作出最棒的雕塑。

blocks.def: honest, sincere, and trusting, sometimes in a way that seems silly
examples:
It has to be said it was rather ingenuous of him to ask a complete stranger to take care of his luggage.
他讓一個完全陌生的人幫自己看管行李，這未免也太天真了。

blocks.def: (of a person or their behaviour) slightly dishonest, or not speaking the complete truth
blocks.trans: （人或其行爲）不夠誠實的，不夠坦白的
examples:
It was disingenuous of her to claim she had no financial interest in the case.
她聲稱自己在這個案子中沒有任何經濟利益，這有些心口不一。

blocks.def: a very small organism that causes disease
examples:
Wash your hands so you don't get germs on the food.
洗洗手，你就不會把細菌弄到食物上了。
 Rats and flies spread germs.
老鼠和蒼蠅傳播病菌。

blocks.def: a small amount, usually one that develops into something large or important
blocks.trans: （通常指發展成為巨大或重要事物）的發端，發源，萌芽
examples:
He found the germ of an idea in an old newspaper.
他的想法萌生於一份舊報紙。

blocks.def: Ideas or information that is germane to a particular subject or situation is connected with and important to it.
blocks.trans: （想法、訊息等）有密切關係的，有重要意義的
examples:
Her remarks could not have been more germane to the discussion.
她的說話跟這次討論密切相關。

blocks.def: to (cause a seed to) start growing
blocks.trans: （使）（種子）發芽，萌芽；（使）開始生長
examples:
The beans will only germinate if the temperature is warm enough.
豆只有在溫度足夠高時才會發芽。

blocks.def: to start developing
examples:
I felt an idea germinating in my head/mind.
我感覺到一個想法開始在腦海中萌生。

blocks.def: to change food in your stomach into substances that your body can use
examples:
I find that I don't digest meat easily.
我發現自己不容易消化肉食。
 Sit still and allow your meal to digest.
靜靜地坐著，讓胃裡的食物消化消化。

blocks.def: to read or hear new information and take the necessary time to understand it
examples:
This chapter is so difficult to digest, I'll have to read it again later.
這一章不容易理解消化，稍後我還得再看一遍。

blocks.def: a short written report providing the most important parts of a larger piece of writing, or one containing recent news
examples:
A digest of the research findings is now available.
研究成果的簡報已經出來了。
 The company publishes a monthly digest of its activities.
該公司每月出一份活動簡報。

blocks.def: to eat or drink something
examples:
The chemicals can be poisonous if ingested.
這些化學製品如果攝入體內可能會引起中毒。

blocks.def: a picture or symbol that represents a word, used in some writing systems, such as the one used in ancient Egypt
blocks.trans: （用於古埃及文字等的）象形符號，象形字

blocks.def: a seed or seeds from a plant, especially a plant like a grass such as rice or wheat
blocks.trans: （尤指像稻穀、小麥等像草一樣的植物的）穀粒，穎果，穀（物）
examples:
grains of wheat/rice
麥／米粒
 Grain (= the crop from food plants like grasses) is one of the main exports of the American Midwest.
穀物是美國中西部地區主要的出口商品。

blocks.def: a very small piece of a hard substance
examples:
grains of sand
沙粒

blocks.def: a very small amount of a particular quality
examples:
There wasn't a grain of truth in anything she said.
她無論說甚麼都沒有半句實話在裡面。
 Anyone with a grain of common sense would have known what to do.
稍微有一點常識的人都會知道應該做甚麼。

blocks.def: the pattern of extremely small spots of black and white or colour, that form a photographic or film image, or one of these small spots
examples:
fine/coarse-grain film
顯影顆粒細（粗）的膠捲

blocks.def: the natural patterns of lines in the surface of wood or cloth
examples:
to cut something along/against the grain
順著紋理／橫對著紋路切開某物

blocks.def: a unit of mass, equal to 0.0648 grams
to establish something such as a belief so firmly that it is not likely to change
blocks.trans: 使…深深印在腦中；使根深蒂固
examples:
We want to ingrain good financial habits in people.
我們想讓人們腦中有很強的理財好習慣。

blocks.def: important and large in degree
examples:
She has all kinds of grand ideas.
她腦子裡都是些經天緯地的想法。
 His job has a grand title, but he's little more than a clerk.
他的工作聽起來名堂很大，可他不過是個職員。

blocks.def: impressive and large or important
examples:
The Palace of Versailles is very grand.
凡爾賽宮非常宏偉。
 They always entertain their guests in grand style.
他們總是舉行盛大宴會款待賓客。

blocks.def: used in the name of a place or building to show that it is large or beautiful and deserves to be admired
blocks.trans: （用在地方或建築物名前表示其規模）大的
examples:
the Grand Hotel
大飯店
 the Grand Canyon
大峽谷
 the Grand Canal
大運河

blocks.def: excellent or enjoyable
blocks.trans: 極好的，出色的；快樂的，稱心的
examples:
We had grand weather on our holiday.
我們去度假時的天氣很好。
 My grandson is a grand little chap.
我孫子是個很了不起的小孩子。
 You've done a grand job.
你做得非常好。

John's new car cost him 20 grand!
約翰買新車花了兩萬！

blocks.def:
informal for
grand piano
to make someone more powerful or important
blocks.trans: 擴大…的權勢；提高…的地位

blocks.def: larger and containing more detail than necessary, or intended to seem important or great
blocks.trans: 誇大的，不切實際的；華而不實的
examples:
grandiose schemes/designs/ideas for making money
不切實際的賺錢計劃／方案／想法

blocks.def: (the art of producing) beautiful writing, often created with a special pen or brush
examples:
There's some wonderful calligraphy in these old manuscripts.
這些古老的手稿中有些地方書法極好。

blocks.def: the study of changes in the number of births, marriages, deaths, etc. in a particular area during a period of time
examples:
historical demography
歷史人口統計學

blocks.def: The demography of an area is the number and characteristics of the people who live in an area, in relation to their age, sex, if they are married or not, etc.
examples:
The increase in the number of young people leaving to work in the cities has had a dramatic impact on the demography of the villages.
越來越多的年輕人到城市工作，這對鄉村人口狀況產生了巨大影響。

blocks.def: showing or expressing thanks, especially to another person
blocks.trans: （尤指對其他人）感激的，表示感謝的
examples:
I'm so grateful (to you) for all that you've done.
你為我做了這一切，我（對你）真是感激不盡。
 If you could get that report finished by Thursday, I'd be very grateful.
如果你能在星期四之前完成那份報告，我將感激不盡。
 After the earthquake we felt grateful to be alive.
地震後，我們大難不死，真是應該感謝上蒼。
 I'm just grateful that I'm not still working for him.
真是謝天謝地，我現在不用再為他工作了。
formal I would be most grateful if you would send me the book immediately.
如果你能馬上把書寄給我，我將感激不盡。

blocks.def: to please someone, or to satisfy a wish or need
blocks.trans: 使高興；使滿意；滿足（某人的願望、需求等）
examples:
We were gratified by the response to our appeal.
呼籲得到積極的響應， 我們感到非常欣慰。
 [ + to infinitive ] He was gratified to see how well his students had done.
看到學生們成績如此出眾，他非常高興。

blocks.def: a person who is not grateful
to make someone like you by praising or trying to please them
examples:
He's always trying to ingratiate himself with his boss.
他總是設法討好老闆。

blocks.def: Ingratiating behaviour is intended to make people like you.
examples:
an ingratiating smile/manner
諂媚的微笑／舉止

blocks.def: the force that attracts objects towards one another, especially the force that makes things fall to the ground
blocks.trans: （尤指地球的）重力，引力，地心引力
examples:
the laws of gravity
萬有引力定律

blocks.def: seriousness
examples:
I don't think you understand the gravity of the situation.
我認為你沒有明白到局勢的嚴重性。

blocks.def: to make a bad situation worse
examples:
Attempts to restrict parking in the city centre have further aggravated the problem of traffic congestion.
在市中心限制停車的試驗方案使交通擠塞的問題更加嚴重。

blocks.def: to make a disease worse
examples:
The treatment only aggravated the condition.
這種療法反而使病情惡化。

blocks.def: to annoy someone
examples:
Stop aggravating me, will you!
別再氣我了，好不好！

blocks.def: something formed by adding together several amounts or things
blocks.trans: 聚集體，集成體；總數，合計
examples:
They purchased an aggregate of 3,000 shares in the company.
他們總共買了這家公司的3000股股票。
 Snowflakes are loose aggregates of ice crystals.
雪花是冰晶鬆散的凝聚體。
 Arsenal lost the second game, but got through to the final on aggregate (= adding together the goals in both matches).
兵工廠隊雖然輸了第二場比賽，但是憑藉進球總數進入了決賽。

blocks.def: small stones used in building
blocks.trans: 骨料，集料，粒料（建築用的小石料）
examples:
Volumes of aggregates, cement, and concrete used in the UK will rise this year.
今年英國骨料、水泥和混凝土的使用量都將上升。

blocks.def: total
examples:
The seven companies have an aggregate turnover of £5.2 million.
這七家公司的總營業額為520萬英鎊。

blocks.def: to combine into a single group or total
extremely bad in a way that is very noticeable
blocks.trans: （錯誤等）極其嚴重的，極壞的，令人震驚的
examples:
It was an egregious error for a statesman to show such ignorance.
一位政界人士表現得如此無知，犯這種錯誤是極不應該的。

blocks.def: (of people) liking to be with other people
examples:
Emma's a gregarious, outgoing sort of person.
艾瑪是個喜歡交際、性情爽直的人。

blocks.def: (especially of animals) living in groups
spoken or physical behaviour that is threatening or involves harm to someone or something
examples:
Some types of dog are bred for aggression.
某些品種的狗是養來起攻擊作用的。
 an act of aggression
攻擊行為

blocks.def: forceful playing in sport that is intended to win points
to break a law or moral rule
blocks.trans: 違背，違反（法律或道德準則）
examples:
Those are the rules, and anyone who transgresses will be severely punished.
那些是規例，任何人違反都要受到嚴懲。

blocks.def: similar to or in agreement with something, so that the two things can both exist or can be combined without problems
examples:
Our goals are congruent; there is no conflict.
我們的目標是一致的，沒有衝突。
 We need the freedom to direct funds in a way that is congruent with local priorities.
我們需要以符合當地優先事項的方式自由引導資金。

blocks.def: used to refer to a shape in mathematics that has the same shape and size as another
examples:
congruent triangles
全等三角形

blocks.def: unusual or different from what is around or from what is generally happening
blocks.trans: 不協調的；不合適的；不一致的
examples:
The new computer looked incongruous in the dark book-filled library.
這台新電腦在放滿書的昏暗圖書館中顯得很不協調。
 It seems incongruous to have a woman as the editor of a men's magazine.
讓一個女人做男性雜誌的編輯似乎不合適。

blocks.def: (of a situation or an event) to have existence or come into existence
examples:
No one knows exactly what happened but several people have been hurt.
沒人確實了解發生了甚麽事，只知道有數人受傷。
 Anything could happen in the next half hour.
接下來的半小時內甚麽事都可能會發生。
 A funny thing happened in the office today.
今天，辦公室裡發生了一件有趣的事。
 I don't want to think about what might have happened if he'd been driving any faster.
我不願意去想假如他再開快一點的話會怎麽樣。

blocks.def: If something happens to someone or something, it has an effect on him, her, or it.
blocks.trans: 發生在（某人）身上；作用於…
examples:
I don't know what I'd do if anything happened to him (= if he was hurt, became ill, or died).
我不知道一旦他出了事我該怎麽辦。
 What happened to your jacket? There's a big rip in the sleeve.
你的夾克怎麽了？袖子上裂了一條大痕。
 What's happened to my pen? (= Where is it?) I put it down there a few moments ago.
我的鋼筆哪裡去了？我剛剛把它放在那裡。

blocks.def: to do or be by chance
examples:
[ + to infinitive ] They happened to look (= looked by chance) in the right place almost immediately.
他們碰巧幾乎一下就找對了地方。
 [ + (that) ] Fortunately it happened (that) there was no one in the house at the time of the explosion.
幸運的是，爆炸發生時，屋子裡沒有人。
 [ + that ] It just so happens that I have her phone number right here.
非常湊巧，我正好有她的電話號碼。
 She happens to like cleaning (= she likes cleaning, although that is surprising).
她剛好就喜歡打掃清潔。
 I happen to think he's right (= I do think so, although you do not).
我真的認爲他是對的。
 As it happened (= although it was not planned), I had a few minutes to spare.
我碰巧有幾分鐘空閒。

blocks.def: perhaps
examples:
Happen it'll rain later on.
過一會兒可能會下雨。

blocks.def: not having an obvious order or plan
blocks.trans: 無秩序的，無計劃的，隨意的
examples:
He tackled the problem in a typically haphazard manner.
像往常一樣，他處理這個問題時也很沒有章法。

blocks.def: to be a sign that something important, and often good, is starting to happen, or to make something publicly known, especially by celebrating or praising it
blocks.trans: 預示…的開始；（尤指透過慶祝或讚揚）宣佈（常指好事）
examples:
The president's speech heralds a new era in foreign policy.
總統的演說預示著一個外交政策新時代的開始。
 This drug has been heralded as a major breakthrough in the fight against breast cancer.
這種藥據稱是在對抗乳癌方面的一個重大突破。

blocks.def: a sign that something will happen, change, etc.
examples:
If this first opera of the season is a herald (= sign) of what is to come, we can expect great things.
如果本季這第一部歌劇是個預示，那麼我們可以期待接下來的劇目會非常精彩。

blocks.def: in the past, a person who carried important messages and made announcements
a person or thing that shows that something is going to happen soon, especially something bad
examples:
a harbinger of doom
毀滅的前兆

blocks.def: to receive money, a house, etc. from someone after they have died
examples:
Who will inherit the house when he dies?
他死後由誰繼承房子？
 All her children will inherit equally.
她所有的子女將平分遺產。

blocks.def: to be born with the same physical or mental characteristics as one of your parents or grandparents
examples:
Rosie inherited her red hair from her mother.
羅茜那頭紅髮遺傳自她母親。

blocks.def: to begin to have responsibility for a problem or situation that previously existed or belonged to another person
blocks.trans: 接手，承擔（遺留的問題等）
examples:
When I took on the job of manager, I inherited certain financial problems.
我擔任經理時接手了一些遺留的財務問題。

blocks.def: the process by which characteristics are given from a parent to their child through the genes
examples:
Diet and exercise can influence a person's weight, but heredity is also a factor.
節食和運動可以影響一個人的體重，而遺傳也是一個因素。

blocks.def: a type of plant whose leaves are used in cooking to give flavour to particular dishes or in making medicine
blocks.trans: （用作調味品或藥材的）香草，藥草
examples:
dried/fresh herbs
乾／新鮮藥草
 Basil, oregano, thyme, and rosemary are all herbs.
羅勒、牛至、百里香和迷迭香都是香草。
 A large range of herbs and spices are used in South Asian cooking.
南亞地區烹飪中使用多種藥草和香料。

blocks.def: (of an animal) eating plants
examples:
The iguanadon was a herbivorous dinosaur.
禽龍是一種食草恐龍。
 Gorillas are primarily herbivorous, eating leaves and stems of shrubs.
大猩猩以食草為主，吃樹葉和灌木莖。

blocks.def: to stick firmly
examples:
A smooth, dry surface helps the tiles adhere to the wall.
平滑、乾燥的牆面有助於瓷磚黏在牆上。

blocks.def: sticky
examples:
an adherent surface
黏性表面

blocks.def: a person who strongly supports a particular person, principle, or set of ideas
examples:
She has long been an adherent of the Communist Party.
長期以來她一直是共產黨的擁護者。

blocks.def: If an argument, set of ideas, or a plan is coherent, it is clear and carefully considered, and each part of it connects or follows in a natural or reasonable way.
blocks.trans: （論據、觀點、計劃）有條理的，連貫的，前後一致的

blocks.def: If someone is coherent, you can understand what that person says.
blocks.trans: （講話）條理清晰的，清楚明白的
examples:
When she calmed down, she was more coherent (= able to speak clearly and be understood).
她冷靜下來後，講話有條理多了。

blocks.def: (the act of having) an opinion or belief that is the opposite of or against what is the official or popular opinion, or an action that shows that you have no respect for the official opinion
blocks.trans: （信奉）異端邪說；（持有）反面觀點，悖論
examples:
Radical remarks like this amount to heresy for most members of the Republican party.
像這樣的激進言論對於大多數共和黨人來說相當於異端邪說。
 She committed the heresy of playing a Lady Gaga song on a classical music station.
她在一個古典音樂節目中打破常規，播放了一首女神卡卡的歌。

blocks.def: a belief that is against the principles of a particular religion
examples:
He was burned at the stake for heresy in the 15th century.
15世紀，他因信仰異教而被燒死在火刑柱上。

blocks.def: (of a belief) against the principles of a particular religion
examples:
The Gnostic gospels were considered heretical.
諾斯底福音曾被視為異端邪說。
 He says that he and his wife are free of sin - a heretical claim for Christians.
他說他們夫妻倆沒有罪過 - 這對基督徒來說是異端言論。

blocks.def: extremely funny and causing a lot of laughter
blocks.trans: 非常滑稽的，引人發笑的
examples:
He didn't like the film at all - I thought it was hilarious.
他根本就不喜歡這部電影——但我覺得它好笑極了。

blocks.def: to give someone strong feelings of happiness and excitement
blocks.trans: 使高興；使興奮；使激動萬分

blocks.def: very bad and shocking
blocks.trans: 極其可怕的；令人震驚的
examples:
a horrific accident/crime
極其可怕的意外事故／駭人的罪行
 horrific injuries
極為嚴重的傷勢

blocks.def: morally very bad
blocks.trans: 令人憎惡的；使人厭惡的；可惡的
examples:
an abhorrent crime
惹人憎惡的罪行
 Racism of any kind is abhorrent to me.
我對任何形式的種族偏見都深惡痛絕。

blocks.def: trying to strongly encourage or persuade someone to do something
blocks.trans: 勸告的，忠告的；勉勵性的，起勉勵作用的
examples:
He delivered his speeches in a formal, hortatory style.
他以一種正式的、勸告式的方式發表了演說。

blocks.def: of or typical of people
examples:
The human body is composed of about 60 percent water.
人體約60%由水組成。
 Early human remains were found in the Dordogne region of France.
在法國的多爾多涅地區發現了早期人類的遺跡。
 Victory in the war was achieved at the cost of great human suffering.
戰爭的勝利是以人類的巨大痛苦為代價換來的。
 The inspector declared the meat fit for human consumption (= in good enough condition for people to eat).
檢查員宣佈這種肉類適合人類食用。
 Of course I make mistakes, I'm only human (= I am not perfect).
我當然會犯錯誤，我只是個凡人。
 The fault was due to human error (= a person making a mistake).
這是人為的錯誤。

blocks.def: a man, woman, or child
examples:
The greatest damage being done to our planet today is that being done by humans.
如今對地球的最大破壞來自我們人類。

blocks.def: cruel and causing suffering to people or animals
examples:
Conditions for prisoners were described as inhumane.
犯人所處的環境被描述為慘無人道。
 Many people believe factory farming is inhumane.
許多人認為工廠化農場經營是不人道的。

blocks.def: not proud or not believing that you are important
examples:
He's very humble about his success.
他對自己的成功十分謙虛。
formal Please accept our humble apologies for the error.
出現這樣的差錯，請接受我們真誠的道歉。
 In my humble opinion (= I want to emphasize that I think that) we should never have bought the car in the first place.
依愚見，首先我們就不應該買這輛汽車。

blocks.def: poor or of a low social rank
examples:
Even when she became rich and famous, she never forgot her humble background.
即使她發了財也出了名，她也永遠沒忘記自己卑微的出身。

blocks.def: ordinary; not special or very important
examples:
At that time she was just a humble mechanic.
那時她只是個不起眼的技工。
humorous Welcome to our humble abode (= our home).
歡迎來到寒舍。

blocks.def: to make someone understand that they are not as important or special as they thought
examples:
He was humbled by the child's generosity.
那個孩子的寬宏大量使他自慚形穢。
 The world champion was humbled (= unexpectedly defeated) by an unknown outsider in last night's race.
昨晚比賽中那位世界冠軍意外地被一位無名小卒擊敗。

blocks.def: having no excitement, interest, or new and different events
blocks.trans: 乏味的，單調的，令人厭倦的
examples:
We lead such a humdrum life/existence.
我們的生活／日子過得真是乏味。
 Most of the work is fairly humdrum.
這工作大部分都相當單調。

blocks.def: the quality of not being proud because you are aware of your bad qualities
examples:
He doesn't have the humility to admit when he's wrong.
他在自己犯錯的時候不會謙虛地承認。
 They might be very rich, but it wouldn't hurt them to show a little humility.
他們可能非常富有，但是表現得謙遜一點對他們不會有甚麼害處。

blocks.def: a chemical element that is the lightest gas, has no colour, taste, or smell, and combines with oxygen to form water
to make your body absorb water or other liquid
examples:
oils that help hydrate your skin
幫助你的皮膚補水的油
 Make sure you hydrate (= drink something) before you exercise. 
鍛煉之前一定要補水。

blocks.def: a chemical that contains water
a small picture or symbol on a computer screen that you point to and click on (= press) with a mouse to give the computer an instruction
a very famous person or thing considered as representing a set of beliefs or a way of life
examples:
Beckham has been one of the country's best-loved sporting icons.
貝克漢是這個國家最受歡迎的體育偶像。

blocks.def: a painting, usually on wood, of Jesus Christ, or of a person considered holy by some Christians, especially in Russia and Greece
blocks.trans: （尤指俄羅斯、希臘等國家的）聖像

blocks.def: strongly opposing generally accepted beliefs and traditions
blocks.trans: 反傳統信仰的；反傳統的
examples:
His plays were fairly iconoclastic in their day.
他的戲劇在當時具有相當的反傳統意味。
 iconoclastic views
反傳統的觀點

blocks.def: a set of beliefs or principles, especially one on which a political system, party, or organization is based
blocks.trans: （尤指作為政治體制、政黨或政治組織基礎的）思想（體系），意識形態
examples:
socialist/capitalist ideology
社會主義／資本主義意識形態
 The people are caught between two opposing ideologies.
民眾被夾在兩種對立的意識形態之間。

blocks.def: a group of words in a fixed order that have a particular meaning that is different from the meanings of each word on its own
examples:
To "have bitten off more than you can chew" is an idiom that means you have tried to do something which is too difficult for you.
have bitten off more than you can chew 是一句成語，意思是試圖承擔力所不及的事。

blocks.def: the style of expression in writing, speech, or music that is typical of a particular period, person, or group
blocks.trans: （某一時期、個人或群體在寫作、言語、音樂方面的）典型表達風格
examples:
Both operas are very much in the modern idiom.
兩部歌劇都很有現代風格。

blocks.def: someone who is admired and respected very much
examples:
a pop/sporting idol
流行音樂偶像／體育明星
 The Hollywood film idols of the 1940s were glamorous figures, adored by millions.
20世紀40年代好萊塢的電影明星魅力四射，受無數人崇拜。

blocks.def: a picture or object that people pray to as part of their religion
examples:
The ancient people of this area worshipped a huge bronze idol in the shape of an elephant.
這個地區的古代居民膜拜一尊象形的青銅巨像。

blocks.def: to behave in a similar way to someone or something else, or to copy the speech or behaviour, etc. of someone or something
examples:
Some of the younger pop bands try to imitate their musical heroes from the past.
一些較年輕的流行樂隊極力模仿心目中昔日的音樂巨星。
 They produce artificial chemicals which exactly imitate particular natural ones.
他們生產酷似某些天然物質的人造化學品。

blocks.def: to copy something achieved by someone else and try to do it as well as they have
blocks.trans: 效仿，模仿；和…競爭，努力趕上
examples:
They hope to emulate the success of other software companies.
他們希望能夠效仿其他軟體公司的成功先例。
 Fitzgerald is eager to emulate Martin's record of three successive world titles.
費茲傑羅渴望能像馬丁那樣創下連奪三次世界冠軍的紀錄。

blocks.def: copying someone or something
examples:
All these magazines are imitative of each other.
所有這些雜誌都是互相抄襲。
 He's an imitative artist, with very little originality in his work.
他是個模仿別人的藝術家，作品中很少有自己的獨創元素。

blocks.def: belonging or relating to an empire or the person or country that rules it
examples:
Imperial China
中華帝國
 Britain's imperial past
英國的帝國史
 the Imperial palace
皇宮
 imperial grandeur
帝國的輝煌

blocks.def: The imperial system of measurement uses units such as inches, miles, and pints.
examples:
Imperial units have in many cases been replaced by metric ones in Britain.
在英國，很多情況下英制已經被公制取代。

blocks.def: extremely important or urgent
blocks.trans: 極重要的；緊急的；迫切的
examples:
[ + that ] The president said it was imperative that the release of all hostages be secured.
總統說當務之急是確保所有人質都獲釋。
 [ + to infinitive ] It's imperative to act now before the problem gets really serious.
必須現在就採取行動，而不是等到問題變得難以收拾。

blocks.def: used to describe the form of a verb that is usually used for giving orders
examples:
In the phrase "Leave him alone!", the verb "leave" is in the imperative form.
在句子 Leave him alone! 中，動詞 leave 用的是祈使語氣。

blocks.def: the form of a verb that is usually used for giving orders
examples:
In the phrase "Leave him alone!", the verb "leave" is an imperative/is in the imperative.
在句子 Leave him alone! 中，動詞 leave 是祈使語氣動詞。

blocks.def: something that is extremely important or urgent
examples:
Getting the unemployed back to work, said the mayor, is a moral imperative.
市長說，讓失業者重返工作崗位是一件道義上必須做的事。

blocks.def: unpleasantly proud and expecting to be obeyed
examples:
an imperious manner/voice
專橫的態度／傲慢的語氣
 She sent them away with an imperious wave of the hand.
她傲慢地揮了揮手，把他們打發走了。

blocks.def: a piece of land completely surrounded by water
examples:
a desert island
荒島
 a Pacific island
太平洋島嶼
 They live on the large Japanese island of Hokkaido.
他們住在日本的主要島嶼北海道。

blocks.def: a particular place that is peaceful, calm, etc., when other surrounding places are the opposite

→ 
traffic island
blocks.trans: 交通島，安全島（同 traffic island）

blocks.def: interested only in your own country or group and not willing to accept different or foreign ideas
the quality of being honest and having strong moral principles that you refuse to change
examples:
No one doubted that the president was a man of the highest integrity.
沒有人懷疑總裁是個光明磊落的人。

blocks.def: someone's high artistic standards or standards of doing their job, and that person's determination not to lower those standards
examples:
Keen to preserve his artistic integrity, he refused several lucrative Hollywood offers.
他十分重視保持自己的藝德，幾次拒絕了好萊塢報酬豐厚的演出邀請。

blocks.def: the quality of being whole and complete
examples:
A modern extension on the old building would ruin its architectural integrity.
在古老建築物上附加擴建的現代建築會破壞建築風格的完整統一。

blocks.def: to become weaker or be destroyed by breaking into small pieces
examples:
The spacecraft disintegrated as it entered the earth's atmosphere.
太空船進入大氣層時解體了。
 The Ottoman Empire disintegrated into lots of small states.
奧斯曼帝國分裂爲許多個小國家。

blocks.def: to become much worse
examples:
The situation disintegrated into chaos.
局勢惡化後陷入混亂狀態。

blocks.def: the movement of goods or people from one place to another
examples:
It is possible to make an insurance claim for any goods lost or damaged in transit.
為在運輸中丟失或受損的貨物索取保險賠償是有可能的。
 The question is whether road transit is cheaper than rail.
問題在於公路運輸是否比鐵路運輸便宜。
 a rapid-transit train
快運列車

blocks.def: a brand name for a type of road vehicle used especially for carrying goods
blocks.trans: （尤指用來運貨的）一種小型車輛，「全順」貨車
examples:
He was seen driving a white Transit van near Leeds.
有人看到他在里茲附近開著一輛白色的「全順」貨車。

blocks.def: not straight or direct
examples:
a circuitous route/path
迂迴路線
 a circuitous (= long and indirect) explanation
轉彎抹角的解釋

blocks.def: travelling from one place to another, usually to work for a short period
examples:
an itinerant journalist/labourer/preacher
四處奔波的記者／流動勞工／巡迴傳道者

blocks.def: belonging or relating to a change, or the process of change, from one form or type to another
examples:
a transitional government
過渡政府

blocks.def: lasting for only a short time
examples:
the transitory nature of life
生命轉瞬即逝的本質

blocks.def: to force someone to leave a particular place
examples:
A number of fans had been ejected from the bar for causing trouble.
一些足球迷因爲鬧事被趕出酒吧。

blocks.def: to order a sports player to leave the playing area during a game because they have broken a rule
blocks.trans: 將（犯規的運動員）罰下場

blocks.def: to leave an aircraft in an emergency using an ejection seat
blocks.trans: （緊急情況下連坐椅一起從飛機中）彈射出來

blocks.def: to come out of a machine when a button is pressed, or to make something do this
examples:
How do you eject the tape?
怎樣才能把磁帶彈出來？
 The coffee machine suddenly ejected a handful of coins.
咖啡自動售賣機裡突然彈出一把硬幣。

blocks.def: a guess about something based on how it seems and not on proof
examples:
There's been a lot of conjecture in the media recently about the marriage.
近期報紙上對這樁婚姻大加猜測。

blocks.def: to guess, based on the appearance of a situation and not on proof
examples:
We'll never know exactly how she died; we can only conjecture.
我們永遠也不會知道她究竟是怎麽死的，只能猜測。
 [ + that ] He conjectured that the company would soon be in financial trouble.
他推測該公司不久就會陷入財務危機。

blocks.def: unhappy, disappointed, or without hope
examples:
She looked a bit dejected when they told her she didn't get the job.
當她知道未能得到那份工作時，她臉上露出一絲失望的表情。

blocks.def: the act of expressing or feeling opposition to or dislike of something or someone
examples:
Her objection to/against the plan is based on incorrect facts.
她對這項計劃的反對基於錯誤的數據。
 A couple of people raised/voiced objections to the proposal.
有幾個人反對這項提議。
 [ + that ] I have no objection except that it may cost more than expected.
我唯一的異議是它的成本可能比預期的要高。

blocks.def: something that you plan to do or achieve
examples:
Her main/prime objective now is simply to stay in power.
她現在的主要目標就是繼續掌權。
 Can the sales team achieve/meet its financial objectives?
銷售人員能否完成財務目標？

blocks.def: based on real facts and not influenced by personal beliefs or feelings
blocks.trans: 客觀的；如實的；不帶個人感情的
examples:
an objective and impartial report
客觀公正的報告
 I can't really be objective when I'm judging my daughter's work.
評價自己女兒的作品時，我的確無法做到客觀。

blocks.def: a person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters
examples:
a British high-court judge
英國高等法院法官
 a US Supreme Court judge
美國最高法院法官

blocks.def: the person who officially decides who is the winner of a competition
examples:
a panel of judges
評審團

blocks.def: a person who has the knowledge to give an opinion about something or is able to decide if someone or something is good or bad
examples:
She's such a bad judge of character.
她很不善於鑒賞別人的品格。
 "I really don't think you should have another drink." "I'll be/Let me be the judge of that (= I am able to make my own decision about that)."
「我真的認為你不該再喝了。」「我自己心裡有數。」

blocks.def: to form, give, or have as an opinion, or to decide about something or someone, especially after thinking carefully
blocks.trans: （尤指認真考慮之後）斷定，判斷，估計
examples:
So far, he seems to be handling the job well, but it's really too soon to judge.
到目前為止，他的工作看起來做得還不錯，但現在下結論還言之過早。
 [ + question word ] It's difficult to judge whether the new system really is an improvement.
很難判斷新系統是否真的有所改進。
 The meeting was judged (to have been) a success.
人們認為會議很成功。
 You shouldn't judge by/on appearances alone.
你不該僅僅以貌取人。
 I'm hopeless at judging distance(s) (= guessing how far it is between places).
我不擅長估算距離。

blocks.def: to express a bad opinion of someone's behaviour, often because you think you are better than them
blocks.trans: （常指因為覺得優於他人而妄加）評論，批評，指責
examples:
You have no right to judge other people because of what they look like or what they believe.
你無權因他人的外貌或信仰而妄下評語。

blocks.def: to officially decide who will be the winner of a competition
examples:
I've been asked to judge the children's poetry competition.
我受邀為兒童詩歌比賽出任評審。

blocks.def: used to express the reasons why you have a particular opinion
examples:
Judging by what he said, I think it's very unlikely that he'll be able to support your application.
從他說的話看來，我認為他不太可能會支持你的申請。

blocks.def: having or showing reason and good judgment in making decisions
examples:
We should make judicious use of the resources available to us.
我們應當審慎使用現有的資源。

blocks.def: a word such as 'and', 'but', 'while', or 'although' that connects words, phrases, and clauses in a sentence
the situation in which events or conditions combine or happen together
examples:
An unfortunate conjunction of circumstances led to his downfall.
一連串不幸事件同時發生，導致了他的下臺。
 There is a team of writers working in conjunction (with each other) on the book.
有一個作家小組在合作撰寫這部書。

blocks.def: in astrology, the situation in which two planets appear to be in the same part of the sky as seen from earth
examples:
Mars and Venus will be in exact conjunction on 1 September.
火星和金星在9月1日會正好相合。

blocks.def: something added or connected to a larger or more important thing
examples:
I hoped I would find the computer course a useful adjunct to my other studies.
我希望上了這門電腦課程後，會使其他科目的學習如虎添翼。

blocks.def: In grammar, an adjunct is an adverb or phrase that gives extra information in a sentence.
blocks.trans: 修飾成分（文法中指在句子中提供附加資料的副詞或者副詞片語）

blocks.def: lacking any clear connection
blocks.trans: 不連貫的，分離的，分裂的
examples:
The play consists of a series of brief, disjunctive scenes.
該劇由一系列簡短的、不連貫的場景組成。

blocks.def: expressing a choice between two or more things, where only one is possible
examples:
Technically speaking, the question is not disjunctive.
嚴格來講，這不是一個選擇疑問句。

blocks.def: a group of people who have been chosen to listen to all the facts in a trial in a law court and to decide if a person is guilty or not guilty, or if a claim has been proved
examples:
members of the jury
陪審團成員
 The jury has/have been unable to return a verdict (= reach a decision).
陪審團未能作出裁決。
 Police officers aren't usually allowed to be/sit/serve on a jury.
警察通常不准當陪審團成員。

blocks.def: a group of people chosen to decide the winner of a competition
to say formally or publicly that you no longer agree with a belief or way of behaving
blocks.trans: 公開放棄，聲明放棄（信念、行為、活動）
examples:
He abjured his religion/his life of dissipation.
他宣佈放棄所信仰的宗教／結束放蕩的生活。

blocks.def: to make something appear by magic, or as if by magic
blocks.trans: 變戲法；用魔法變出；像變魔術般變出
examples:
In an instant, the magician had conjured (up) a dove from his hat.
魔術師眨眼間便從他的帽子裡變出了一隻鴿子。

blocks.def: fairness in the way people are dealt with
examples:
There's no justice in the world when people can be made to suffer like that.
如果人們被迫遭受這樣的痛苦，那麼世上就沒有公平正義可言了。
 The winner has been disqualified for cheating, so justice has been done (= a fair situation has been achieved).
獲勝者因舞弊而被取消了資格，正義得以伸張。

blocks.def: the system of laws in a country that judges and punishes people
examples:
the justice system in this country consists of a series of law courts at different levels.
這個國家的司法體系由各級法庭組成。
 The police are doing all they can to bring those responsible for the bombing to justice.
警方正竭盡全力將爆炸案的涉案歹徒繩之以法。
 They are victims of a miscarriage of justice (= when the law has been carried out wrongly).
他們是審判不公的受害者。
 He has been accused of obstructing the course of justice (= preventing the law being put into action).
他被控阻礙司法公正。

blocks.def: a judge in a law court
examples:
The president is expected to name a new Supreme Court justice within the next few days.
預計總統會在未來幾天內任命一名新的最高法院法官。
 Justice Ben Overton
班‧奧佛頓法官

blocks.def: used before the name of a judge in the High Court
blocks.trans: （用於英國高等法院的法官姓名前）法官
examples:
Mr Justice Ellis
法官艾利斯先生

blocks.def: to give or to be a good reason for
blocks.trans: 為…辯護；證明…正當（或有理、正確）；是…的正當理由
examples:
[ + -ing verb ] I can't really justify taking another day off work.
我真的找不出理由再多休一天假了。
 Are you sure that these measures are justified?
你確定這些措施合理嗎？

blocks.def: If you justify yourself, you give a good reason for what you have done.
examples:
It was the only thing that I could do - I don't have to justify myself to anyone.
這是我唯一能做的——我不必向任何人解釋。

blocks.def: relating to a young person who is not yet old enough to be considered an adult
examples:
juvenile crime/offenders
青少年犯罪／少年罪犯

blocks.def: silly and typical of a child
examples:
juvenile behaviour
幼稚的行為
 a juvenile sense of humour
帶稚氣的幽默感

blocks.def: a young person
a feeling of great happiness, especially because of a success
blocks.trans: （尤指因成功而感到）歡欣，喜氣洋洋
examples:
There was jubilation in the crowd as the winning goal was scored.
球隊攻入致勝一球時，人群一片歡騰。

blocks.def: to make someone look or feel young and energetic again
blocks.trans: 使年輕；使恢復活力；使青春煥發
examples:
She felt rejuvenated by her fortnight in the Bahamas.
在巴哈馬群島度了兩週假，她覺得自己變年輕了。

blocks.def: to make an organization or system more effective by introducing new methods, ideas, or people
blocks.trans: 使（組織或體制）恢復活力
examples:
He has decided to rejuvenate the team by bringing in a lot of new, young players.
他決定大批引進年輕的新隊員，使球隊恢復活力。

blocks.def: to work with someone else for a special purpose
examples:
Two writers collaborated on the script for the film.
兩位作家合寫了這部電影的劇本。
 A German company collaborated with a Swiss firm to develop the product.
一家德國公司與一家瑞士小公司合作開發該產品。
 The British and Italian police collaborated in catching the terrorists.
英國警方和義大利警方通力合作，抓住了恐怖分子。

blocks.def: to work with an enemy who has taken control of your own country
examples:
Anyone who was suspected of collaborating with the occupying forces was arrested.
任何涉嫌與佔領軍勾結的人都被逮捕了。

blocks.def: needing a lot of time and effort
blocks.trans: 耗時費力的；艱巨的，艱難的
examples:
a laborious task
艱巨的任務

blocks.def: the form of an adjective or adverb that expresses that the thing or person being described has more of the particular quality than anything or anyone else of the same type
blocks.trans: （形容詞或副詞的）最高級形式
examples:
"Richest" is the superlative of "rich".
richest 是 rich 的最高級（形式）。
 The magazine article contained so many superlatives that I found it hard to believe that what it was saying was true.
雜誌上的這篇文章用了這麼多最高級修飾詞，讓我覺得可信度不高。

blocks.def: of the highest quality; the best
blocks.trans: 品質最優的，最好的，最優秀的
examples:
We went to a superlative restaurant.
我們去了一家最好的餐館。

blocks.def: relating to the superlative of an adjective or adverb
blocks.trans: （與某一形容詞或副詞的）最高級有關的

blocks.def: the position north or south of the equator measured from 0° to 90°
an area near to a particular latitude
examples:
At these latitudes the sun does not rise at all on winter days.
處於這些緯度的地區冬天根本就見不到太陽。

blocks.def: freedom to behave, act, or think in the way you want to
examples:
Courts can show a considerable degree of latitude when it comes to applying the law.
法庭在依法量刑斷案方面有較大的自由度。

blocks.def: to make a liquid weaker by mixing in something else
examples:
Dilute the juice (with water) before you drink it.
果汁先（用水）稀釋一下再喝。

blocks.def: to reduce the strength of a feeling, action, etc.
examples:
These measures are designed to dilute public fears about the product's safety.
採取這些措施是為了減輕公眾對該產品安全的恐慌。

blocks.def: made weaker by diluting
examples:
dilute hydrochloric acid
經過稀釋的鹽酸

blocks.def: a time when people vote in order to choose someone for a political or official job
examples:
The government is expected to call an election (= allow the country to vote) very soon.
預計政府會很快舉行大選。
 Local government elections will take place in May.
地方政府選舉將在五月份舉行。
 The first election results have started to come in.
初步選舉結果開始揭曉。

blocks.def: Methods, beliefs, ideas, etc. that are eclectic combine whatever seem the best or most useful things from many different areas or systems, rather than following a single system.
blocks.trans: 不拘一格的；相容並蓄的；博採眾長的
examples:
an eclectic style/approach
相容並蓄的風格 ／ 博採眾長的方法
 an eclectic taste in literature
對文學廣泛的興趣

blocks.def: If someone has a predilection for something, they like it a lot.
examples:
Ever since she was a child, she has had a predilection for spicy food.
從孩提時起，她就偏好辛辣食物。

blocks.def: connected with the law
blocks.trans: 法律的，法律上的，法律方面的
examples:
legal advice
法律建議
 a legal obligation/requirement
法律義務／要求
 legal status
法律地位
 your legal rights
你的法定權利
 legal action/proceedings
法律行動／程序
 my legal representatives (= my lawyers)
我的法律代表

blocks.def: allowed by the law
examples:
Is abortion legal in your country?
墮胎在你們國家是否合法？

blocks.def: used to refer to a standard size of paper in the US, 8.5 inches by 14 inches
blocks.trans: 法律規格紙（在美國使用的一種紙張大小的標準，長14英寸，寬8.5英寸）
examples:
Your poster should be on letter or legal size paper.
你的海報必須是標準信紙或法律規格紙的大小。

blocks.def: loyalty and support for a ruler, country, group, or belief
blocks.trans: （對統治者、國家、群體或信仰的）忠誠，忠貞；擁戴，擁護
examples:
Soldiers have to swear allegiance to the Crown/the King.
士兵必須宣誓效忠國王。
 In many American schools, the students pledge allegiance (to the flag) at the beginning of the school day.
在很多美國學校裡，學生每天上課前要（向國旗）進行宣誓。
 As an Englishman who'd lived for a long time in France, he felt a certain conflict of allegiances when the two countries played soccer.
作為一個在法國生活了很長時間的英國人，當兩國足球隊比賽時，對於要支持哪一方，他的內心會有一番思想鬥爭。

blocks.def: allowed by law
blocks.trans: 合法的，正當的，法律允許的
examples:
The army must give power back to the legitimate government.
軍隊必須將權力交還給合法政府。

blocks.def: reasonable and acceptable
blocks.trans: 合理的，可接受的，得到認可的
examples:
He claimed that the restaurant bill was a legitimate business expense.
他聲稱飯店帳單是一筆合理的業務開支。

blocks.def: A legitimate child is one whose parents are legally married at the time of his or her birth.
to make something legal or acceptable
examples:
The government fears that talking to terrorists might legitimate their violent actions.
政府擔心與恐怖分子談判可能會使他們的暴力行為得到認可。

blocks.def: a device like a box that moves up and down, carrying people or goods from one floor of a building to another or taking people up and down underground in a mine
a conveyor (= moving strip) that can be used for removing goods from a ship, putting bags onto an aircraft, moving grain, etc.
blocks.trans: （裝有傳送帶，用以卸貨、裝貨或搬運糧食入庫的）升降機，起卸機

blocks.def: to make something bad such as pain or problems less severe
examples:
The drugs did nothing to alleviate her pain/suffering.
這些藥物對減輕她的病痛／痛苦沒有絲毫作用。

blocks.def: to raise something or lift something up
examples:
The platform was elevated by means of hydraulic legs.
平臺由液壓支架抬升起來。

blocks.def: to make someone or something more important or to improve something
examples:
They want to elevate the status of teachers.
他們想提高教師的社會地位。
 These factors helped to elevate the town to the position of one of the most beautiful in the country.
這些因素提高了該鎮的聲望，使之成爲該國十大最具魅力小鎮之一。

blocks.def: to be given a higher rank or social position
examples:
He has been elevated to deputy manager.
他已被提升爲副經理。
 She was elevated to the peerage (= was made a peer).
她被封爲貴族。

blocks.def: to add a substance to bread or another food made with flour to make it increase in size when it is cooked
to make something less boring
examples:
Even a speech on a serious subject should be leavened with a little humour.
即使是一篇題目很嚴肅的演講也應該包含一些幽默的內容在裡面。

blocks.def: humour or lack of seriousness, especially during a serious occasion
examples:
a brief moment of levity amid the solemn proceedings
嚴肅議程中的輕鬆一刻

blocks.def: (a list of) all the words used in a particular language or subject, or a dictionary
blocks.trans: （某語言或學科的）全部辭彙；詞典

blocks.def: a dictionary
using too many words and therefore boring or difficult to read or listen to
blocks.trans: 冗長的；囉唆的；好長篇大論的
examples:
The author's prolix style has done nothing to encourage sales of the book.
這個作者冗長的寫作風格無益促進該書的銷售。

blocks.def: respecting and allowing many different types of beliefs or behaviour
blocks.trans: 自由開放的，開放的，開明的
examples:
a liberal society/attitude
自由開放的社會／態度
 Her parents were far more liberal than mine.
她父母比我父母開明得多。

blocks.def: (of a political party or a country) believing in or allowing more personal freedom and development towards a fairer sharing of wealth and power within society
blocks.trans: （指政黨或國家）自由的，開放的

blocks.def: giving or given in a generous way
blocks.trans: 慷慨的，大方的，毫不吝嗇的
examples:
He was very liberal with the wine.
對於酒他毫不吝嗇。

blocks.def: not exact; without attention to or interest in detail
blocks.trans: 不確切的，模糊的，籠統的
examples:
a liberal interpretation of the law
對法律的籠統解釋

blocks.def: someone who respects many different types of beliefs or behaviour
examples:
He's a good old-fashioned liberal.
他是個老式的自由主義者。

blocks.def: limiting freedom of expression, thought, behaviour, etc.
blocks.trans: （言論、思想、行為等）不自由的，不開明的，狹隘的
examples:
illiberal policies
專制的政策

blocks.def: producing a great number or amount of something
examples:
He was probably the most prolific songwriter of his generation.
他可能是他這一代中最多產的歌曲作家。
 Rabbits and other rodents are prolific (= have a lot of babies).
兔子和其他囓齒類動物繁殖能力都很強。

blocks.def: to increase a lot and suddenly in number
examples:
Small businesses have proliferated in the last ten years.
在過去的十年裡，小型企業大量湧現。

blocks.def: the belief in and worship of a god or gods, or any such system of belief and worship
examples:
the Christian religion
基督教

blocks.def: an activity that someone is extremely enthusiastic about and does regularly
blocks.trans: 癡迷的活動；極愛好的活動
examples:
Football is a religion for these people.
這些人對足球入了迷。

blocks.def: If something is obligatory, you must do it because of a rule or law, etc.
blocks.trans: （根據規定、法律等）必須履行的，強制性的，有義務的
examples:
The medical examination before you start work is obligatory.
工作前必須先體檢。
 [ + to infinitive ] The statute made it obligatory for all healthy males between 14 and 60 to work.
這條法令規定所有年齡在14至60歲的男子必須工作。

blocks.def: expected because it usually happens
blocks.trans: （因為常發生而）必然的，預料之中的；慣常的
examples:
Several Secret Service agents surrounded the President, all wearing the obligatory raincoat and hat.
幾名特工圍在總統四周，當然是一律穿著風雨衣，戴著帽子。

blocks.def: the main shape or edge of something, without any details
examples:
She drew the outline of the boat and then coloured it in.
她畫了這隻船的草圖，然後給它著色。

blocks.def: as a shape with an edge but without any details
examples:
The mountain was visible only in outline as the light faded.
光線暗了下來，只能看見山的輪廓。

blocks.def: a description of the main facts about something
examples:
If you read the minutes of the meeting, they'll give you a broad outline of what was discussed.
如果你看了會議記錄，就會知道討論的大概內容。
 Some novelists start by writing an outline (= plan of the main points of the story).
有些小說家創作時會先寫提綱。

blocks.def: to draw the main shape or edge of something
examples:
The area we're interested in is outlined in red on the map.
我們感興趣的地區已經用紅筆在地圖上勾出來了。

blocks.def: to give the main facts about something
examples:
At the interview she outlined what I would be doing.
面試時，她簡要介紹了我將要從事的工作。

blocks.def: to describe or mark the edge of something
examples:
The main characters are clearly delineated in the first chapter.
主要人物在第一章裡得到了清晰的描述。
 The boundary of the car park is delineated by a low brick wall.
一堵矮牆標出了停車場的邊界。

blocks.def: to draw a line under a word, especially in order to show its importance
blocks.trans: （尤指爲了強調）在（詞語）下面畫線
examples:
All the technical words have been underlined in red.
所有術語的下面都畫了紅線。

blocks.def: to emphasize
examples:
She gave some shocking examples to underline the seriousness of the situation.
她舉了一些令人震驚的例子以強調形勢的嚴峻。
 To underline their disgust, the crowd started throwing bottles at the stage.
爲了宣洩他們的厭惡，觀眾們開始朝舞臺上扔瓶子。

blocks.def: to give up something such as a responsibility or claim
examples:
He has relinquished his claim to the throne.
他放棄了繼承王位的要求。
 She relinquished control of the family investments to her son.
她把家庭投資的掌控權移交給了兒子。

blocks.def: to unwillingly stop holding or keeping something
blocks.trans: （不情願地）鬆開，放開，交出，讓予
examples:
She relinquished her hold/grip on the steering wheel.
她鬆開了握著軚盤的手。

blocks.def: a person, usually young, who behaves in a way that is illegal or not acceptable to most people
blocks.trans: （通常指年輕的）違法者；不良青少年
examples:
juvenile delinquents
青少年罪犯

blocks.def: illegal or not acceptable, or behaving in a way that is illegal or not acceptable
examples:
They are carrying out research on the causes of delinquent behaviour among young people.
他們正在研究青少年違法行為的產生原因。
 delinquent teenagers
少年犯

blocks.def: late (in paying money owed)
blocks.trans: 遲付欠款的，未按時還款的，拖欠的
examples:
She has been delinquent in paying her taxes.
她一直沒有按時納稅。

blocks.def: an occasion when the sun disappears from view, either completely or partly, while the moon is moving between it and the earth, or when the moon becomes darker while the shadow of the earth moves over it
examples:
a solar/lunar eclipse
日／月蝕
 On Wednesday there will be a total/partial eclipse of the sun.
週三將有一次日全／偏蝕。

blocks.def: a situation in which something becomes less important
examples:
The eclipse of the ruling political party was inevitable.
執政黨大勢已去，無可挽回。
 His remarkable contribution to literature has been too long in eclipse.
他對文學的傑出貢獻已被人們遺忘太久了。

blocks.def: to make an eclipse of the moon or sun
examples:
The moon will be totally eclipsed at 12.10 p.m. 
晚上十二點十分會出現月全蝕。

blocks.def: to make another person or thing seem much less important, good, or famous
blocks.trans: 掩沒…的重要性（或優點、聲譽等）；淩駕…之上；光芒蓋過…
examples:
The economy has eclipsed all other issues during this election campaign.
這次大選期間，經濟問題成為壓倒性的重大議題。

blocks.def: unable to read and write
examples:
A surprising percentage of the population is illiterate.
人口中文盲的比例令人吃驚。

blocks.def: knowing little or nothing about a particular subject
blocks.trans: （對某專題）所知甚少的，外行的
examples:
computer illiterate
對電腦所知甚少的
 financially/technologically illiterate
對金融／技術所知甚少的

blocks.def: someone who is illiterate
relating to the period when humans used tools and weapons made of stone
examples:
The Paleolithic Period is sometimes called the Old Stone Age.
The Paleolithic Period（舊石器時代）有時被稱作 the Old Stone Age。

blocks.def: too large, too regular, or without interesting differences, and unwilling or unable to be changed
examples:
monolithic state-run organizations
龐大的國營機構

blocks.def: to give something to someone as their share of a total amount, to use in a particular way
examples:
The government is allocating £10 million for health education.
政府將撥出1000萬英鎊作為健康教育經費。
 [ + two objects ] As project leader, you will have to allocate people jobs/allocate jobs to people.
作為企劃案負責人，你必須給大家分派工作。
 It is not the job of the investigating committee to allocate blame for the disaster/to allocate blame to individuals.
調查委員會的任務不是確定誰該為這場災難負責任／哪些人應該負責任。

blocks.def: the place where something happens or the central area of interest in something being discussed
blocks.trans: 發生地；關注的焦點；討論的中心
examples:
The locus of decision-making is sometimes far from the government's offices.
決策的地點有時根本就不在政府的辦公室。

blocks.def: conversation that is written for a book, play, or film
examples:
The play contained some very snappy/witty dialogue.
這齣戲裡有一些非常俏皮／風趣的對白。
 Act Two begins with a short dialogue between father and son.
第二幕以父子間的簡短對白開場。

blocks.def: formal talks between opposing countries, political groups, etc.
blocks.trans: （敵對國家、政治團體間的）對話
examples:
The rebel leaders stated that they are willing to enter into dialogue with the government.
叛軍首領發表聲明說他們願意與政府進行對話。
 The two sides have at last begun to engage in a constructive dialogue.
雙方終於開始進行建設性對話。

blocks.def: a person who supports a particular belief or political system, especially an unpopular one, and speaks or writes in defence of it
blocks.trans: （尤指不受歡迎的政治信仰或制度的）辯護者，辯解者
examples:
communism and its apologists
共產主義及其辯護者
 There are few apologists for the old system.
很少有人為舊制度辯護。

blocks.def: (an example of) an indirect way of saying something, especially something unpleasant
blocks.trans: （尤指對不好的事情的）迂迴曲折的說法；婉轉語，遁詞
examples:
"Economical with the truth" is a circumlocution for "lying".
「對實情惜字如金」是「撒謊」的委婉說法。
 Politicians are experts in circumlocution.
政客極擅長拐彎抹角地講話。

blocks.def: (of words and expressions) informal and more suitable for use in speech than in writing
blocks.trans: （詞語或表達方式）口語的，俗語的，非正式的
examples:
colloquial speech
口語

blocks.def: Someone who is loquacious talks a lot.
using very few words to express what you mean
examples:
She had a laconic wit.
她說話言簡意賅。

blocks.def: a long speech by one person
blocks.trans: （一個人的）滔滔不絕的話，長篇大論
examples:
disapproving He subjected me to a monologue on his last stay in hospital.
他向我滔滔不絕地講述了他上次住院的經歷。

blocks.def: a short play for one actor
examples:
Alan Bennett wrote a series of monologues called "Talking Heads".
亞倫‧班奈特寫了一系列名為《頭腦獨白》的獨角戲。

blocks.def: preventing disease
examples:
Some dentists are convinced that the addition of fluoride in water is ineffective as a prophylactic treatment.
有些牙醫堅信在水中加氟化物不是有效的預防措施。

blocks.def: something that is intended to prevent disease

a 
condom
a speech in a play that the character speaks to himself or herself or to the people watching rather than to the other characters
examples:
Hamlet's soliloquy starts "To be or not to be".
哈姆雷特的獨白以「生存還是毀滅」開頭。

blocks.def: living for a long time
examples:
To what do you attribute your longevity?
你的長壽歸功於哪些因素？

blocks.def: remaining popular or useful for a long time
examples:
For longevity in car design, you really need to keep it simple.
為了讓汽車設計延續長久，你真的必須保持簡單。

blocks.def: A long-winded speech, letter, article, etc. is too long, or uses too many words.
to explain something or make something clear
examples:
I don't understand. You'll have to elucidate.
我不懂，你得解釋一下。
 The reasons for the change in weather conditions have been elucidated by several scientists.
已經有好幾位科學家對天氣狀況變化的原因作過解釋。

blocks.def: clearly expressed and easy to understand, or (of a person) thinking or speaking clearly
blocks.trans: 清晰的，明瞭的；（人）頭腦清醒的，說話清楚的
examples:
She gave a clear and lucid account of her plans for the company's future.
她清楚明瞭地講述了自己對公司未來的規劃。
 The drugs she's taking make her drowsy and confused, but there are times when she's quite lucid.
她吃的藥會讓她感到頭暈、意識模糊，但有時頭腦卻很清醒。

blocks.def: (especially of a business, job, or activity) producing a lot of money
blocks.trans: （尤指生意、職位或活動）賺錢的，盈利的
examples:
The merger proved to be very lucrative for both companies.
事實證明，這次兼併使兩間公司都獲利豐厚。

blocks.def: an idea or belief that is not true
examples:
He had no illusions about his talents as a singer.
他對自己作為歌手的才華不抱幻想。
 I'm under no illusions (= I understand the truth) about the man I married.
我對我所嫁的男人不抱幻想。
 My boss is labouring under the illusion that (= wrongly believes that) the project will be completed on time.
我的老闆還存有工程能按時完成的幻想。

blocks.def: something that is not really what it seems to be
examples:
A large mirror in a room can create the illusion of space.
房間裡放面大鏡子能給人一種房間很寬敞的錯覺。
 The impression of calm in the office is just an illusion.
辦公室裡的平靜其實只是種假像。

blocks.def: containing a lot of allusions
blocks.trans: 影射的，暗指的；間接提到的；引用典故的
examples:
Her music is witty, ironic, and allusive.
她的音樂作品詼諧、諷刺，富含典故。

blocks.def: to act together secretly or illegally in order to deceive or cheat someone
examples:
It was suspected that the police had colluded with the witnesses.
警方涉嫌與證人暗中串通。

blocks.def: to make someone believe something that is not true
examples:
He's deluding himself if he thinks he's going to be promoted this year.
如果他認為今年將獲得晉升，那他是在自己騙自己。

blocks.def: If something that you want eludes you, you do not succeed in achieving it.
blocks.trans: 使達不到；使做不成；使不能實現
examples:
The gold medal continues to elude her.
金牌依舊和她無緣。
 They had minor breakthroughs but real success eluded them.
他們獲得了一些小的突破，但沒有獲得真正的成功。

blocks.def: to not be caught by someone
examples:
They eluded the police by fleeing.
他們紛紛逃走，避開了警方的搜捕。

blocks.def: If a piece of information eludes you, you cannot remember it.
examples:
I know who you mean but her name eludes me.
我知道你說的是誰，但就是想不起她的名字了。

blocks.def: difficult to describe, find, achieve, or remember
blocks.trans: 難以描述（或找到、達到、記起）的；困難的
examples:
The answers to these questions remain as elusive as ever.
這些問題的答案仍然是不得而知。
 Success, however, remained elusive for her.
但是對她來說，成功仍然不可企及。
 elusive memories
模糊的記憶

blocks.def: disappointed and unhappy because of discovering the truth about something or someone that you liked or respected
blocks.trans: 理想破滅的；不抱幻想的
examples:
He's become a disillusioned man.
他成了夢想破滅的人。
 All the other teachers are thoroughly disillusioned with their colleague.
其他教師都對他們的同事感到徹底失望了。

blocks.def: not real and based on illusion
blocks.trans: 虛假的，幻覺的，不實際的
examples:
Their hopes of a peaceful solution turned out to be illusory.
他們希望和平解決的想法最終證實是不實際的。

blocks.def: stupid or unreasonable and deserving to be laughed at
examples:
a ludicrous idea/suggestion
可笑的想法／荒謬的建議
 He looked ludicrous in that suit!
他穿上那套衣服看上去很可笑！

blocks.def: (especially of a description) shocking because involving violence, sex, or immoral activity
blocks.trans: （尤指描述）駭人的，令人毛骨悚然的
examples:
